_description: This file defines the typography system for TaskFlow. Typography is organized by hierarchy (heading, body, functional) with specific fonts, sizes, weights, and spacing for each level.
_swiftUsage: In SwiftUI, use these with .font() modifier. Create a Font extension or ViewModifier for consistent application: .font(.h1), .font(.bodyRegular), etc.
_accessibility: All fonts should support Dynamic Type to respect user's preferred text size. Use UIFontMetrics for scaling.

fontFamily._comment: Primary font families used throughout TaskFlow

heading._notes: Used for all headings and titles. SF Pro Display is the system display font, optimized for large sizes.

body._notes: Used for body text, descriptions, and content. SF Pro Text is optimized for readability at text sizes.

mono._notes: Used for code snippets, dates, and technical information. SF Mono is the system monospace font.

fontFamily._designRationale: Using Apple's system fonts (SF Pro) ensures native appearance, automatic dark mode support, and optimal rendering across all Apple platforms without shipping custom fonts.

headings._comment: Heading levels for hierarchical information. Used for page titles, section headers, and emphasized text.

h1.name: Display Heading
h1._notes: Largest heading. Used once per screen at most. Maps to .largeTitle in SwiftUI.

h2.name: Section Heading
h2._notes: Second level heading. Maps to .title in SwiftUI.

h3.name: Subsection Heading
h3._notes: Third level heading. Maps to .title2 in SwiftUI.

h4.name: Minor Heading
h4._notes: Fourth level heading. Maps to .title3 in SwiftUI.

h5.name: Caption Heading
h5._notes: Fifth level heading. Maps to .headline in SwiftUI.

body._comment: Body text for content, descriptions, and readable information.

large.name: Large Body
large._notes: Default body text size. Maps to .body in SwiftUI.

regular.name: Regular Body
regular._notes: Slightly smaller body text. Maps to .callout in SwiftUI.

small.name: Small Body
small._notes: Smallest readable body text. Maps to .footnote in SwiftUI.

functional._comment: Functional text for UI elements, controls, and metadata.

button.name: Button Text
button._notes: Button text should be semibold for emphasis. Maps to .body.weight(.semibold) in SwiftUI.

label.name: Label Text
label._notes: Small, bold text for labels. Maps to .caption.weight(.medium) in SwiftUI.

caption.name: Caption Text
caption._notes: Smallest text for non-critical information. Maps to .caption2 in SwiftUI.

date.name: Date Text
date._notes: Medium weight for dates to stand out from body text. Can use SF Mono for technical precision.

typographyScale._comment: Scale ratios for consistent sizing across the system
typographyScale._notes: Using a major third scale (1.25) creates harmonious sizing between headings. Each heading level is 1.25x larger than the next.

lineHeight._notes: Tight for headings, normal for body, relaxed for long-form content.

letterSpacing._comment: Letter spacing adjustments for different sizes

positive.reason: Slightly more letter spacing improves readability at large sizes

negative.reason: Tight letter spacing improves readability at small sizes

letterSpacing._notes: System fonts have built-in letter spacing. Adjust only when needed for visual balance.

textStyles._comment: Pre-defined text style combinations for common patterns

taskTitle._usage: Primary task title in list items

dynamicType._notes: All text should respect user's Dynamic Type preference. Use UIFontMetrics.scaledValue(for:) for custom sizes.

minimumSize._notes: WCAG guidelines recommend 11px minimum for body text. Always test at smallest text size.

readability._notes: Optimal line height for readability. Adjust based on font size and line length.

_implementationTips.1: Create SwiftUI Font extension: static func h1() -> Font { .system(size: 34, weight: .bold) }
_implementationTips.2: Use ViewModifier for consistent application: struct BodyText: ViewModifier { func body(content: Content) -> some View { content.font(.body).foregroundColor(.primary) } }
_implementationTips.3: Support Dynamic Type with scaledFont() extension: func scaledFont(size: CGFloat) -> Font { Font.system(size: UIFontMetrics.default.scaledValue(for: size)) }
_implementationTips.4: Prefer system fonts (.title, .body, .caption) over custom sizes for automatic Dynamic Type support
_implementationTips.5: Test typography at different text sizes (Extra Small to Accessible Extra Large) during development

_references.SFProDisplay: Optimized for headlines and large text, available in 9 weights
_references.SFProText: Optimized for body text, available in 9 weights
_references.SFMono: Monospace font for code and technical text, available in 6 weights
